natural solution: Using the sum-to-product formula, we have \begin{align} \cos 12^{\circ} + \cos 48^{\circ} &= 2 \cos 30^{\circ} \cos 18^{\circ}, \\ \sin 12^{\circ} + \sin 48^{\circ} &= 2 \sin 30^{\circ} \cos 18^{\circ}.
Hence, the imaginary part is $\boxed{0}$. (See if you can also find a geometric solution!)

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z :: complex
assumes h0 : "z = (cos (rad_of_deg 12) + \<i> * sin (rad_of_deg 12)) + (cos (rad_of_deg 48) + \<i> * sin (rad_of_deg 48))"
shows  "Im (z ^ 6) = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the imaginary part of \[(\cos12^\circ+i\sin12^\circ+\cos48^\circ+i\sin48^\circ)^6.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 Using the sum-to-product formula, we have \begin{align} \cos 12^{\circ} + \cos 48^{\circ} &= 2 \cos 30^{\circ} \cos 18^{\circ}, \\ \sin 12^{\circ} + \sin 48^{\circ} &= 2 \sin 30^{\circ} \cos 18^{\circ}.
 \\ \end{align}Therefore, \begin{align} (\cos 12^{\circ} + i \sin 12^{\circ} + \cos 48^{\circ} + i \sin 48^{\circ})^6 &= [2\cos 18^{\circ} (\cos 30^{\circ} + i \sin 30^{\circ})]^6 \\ &= 64\cos^6 18^{\circ} (\cos 180^{\circ} + i \sin 180^{\circ}) \\
 &= -64\cos^6 18^{\circ}, \end{align}which is real.
 Hence, the imaginary part is $\boxed{0}$. (See if you can also find a geometric solution!)
 *)
